pros: Direct managers and colleagues are kind and helpful people. Beautiful workplace with bistro, canteen, huge gym, yoga room, bbq pits. Do my work, no complains, go home. No OT (only if you do work non-stop)
cons: Higher up (some) toxic manger/boss. Does not listen to reason, shouts and increases voice in public to shame you and demeans staff / no respect. Embarrasses staffs in public, asks staffs to "don't talk back" everytime we try to explain something, micromanages staff, constantly increases our workload without asking if our plates are full, hence everyone doing 2-3 person work. (Here, she will tell us that everyone is busy too) Shut us down when we try to tell her our concerns. can't complain to HR because she will mark us if she finds out from them. Asks us to talk to her directly if has any complains, but we end up get scolding instead. No one want to talk to her anymore. No understanding, no empathy. Treats her staff like trash and animals, but treats those higher ranking staff like gods. Overall toxic department. higherups loves her, low ranking staffs can only suck it up. Entire department will have serious mental health issues sooner or later.

review_title: Good initiatives in providing work life balance, could have better benefits for employees
pros: The company has implemented good initiatives in improving employee benefits and work-life balance since the easing of COVID-19 restrictions. Employee benefits are relatively ok, with a group medical plan as well as Singtel staff discount for mobile plans.
cons: Although the company provides options for more work-life balance, some project team leads are advocating for more OTs and require employees to stay past normal working hours for good performance bonus reviews. (To them staying in the office longer = good performance??) There is also no compensation for OT. When project deadlines are near, employees are required to sacrifice off days, or personal time with no additional compensation. The only compensation is off in-lieu days, where they give back the day they took your weekend. Working on-site in the vendor office has no fixed working space, getting pushed around by vendor staff.

pros: - No office politics - A bunch of good collogues

"You" could have said the company is not doing well; thus layoffs are needed. Please do not give invalid reasons to fire people; this is outrageous. - There need to be transparent conversations between leaders and employees. The management should be more upfront with all the employees about company performance. - Leaders only focus on gaining credits. Despite verbally stressing their concerns for all employees' professional development, the leaders did nothing. For example, there is no monthly and quarterly performance review from the direct reporting managers. - The job scope is manageable: Many experienced HR professionals have been hired to perform simple job scopes, which junior employees can accomplish.

review_title: 100% of you all must be in office at all times.
pros:
- Great colleagues.
- Great office location.
- Good salary.
cons:
- Official working hours: 9:00am - 6:00pm
Actual working hours: 9:00am - 11:30pm

- Management: Oh you are taking leave tomorrow? Can you postpone it to next month instead? 
Next month, Management: Sorry, but we need you, can you postpone your leave again to next month?

- Management: This haven't been approved yet, but I need you to work on it first, we can't lose any time to wait for the approval. 
In the end, the approval was not granted because it was deemed unecessary, time and effort wasted.

- Management: Please do correct timelog so we can calculate the project cost easily.
Reality: Worked 16 hours today, only able to timelog 8 hours per day because it was locked by the management. This caused everyone in the project to work 16 hours per day, and management is questioning why the project is so slow in the progression.

•Scope of work is narrow, the workload is unevenly high (OT) Might be stuck in a dead end role. 

• Leave can only be brought forward for 4 months and not the entire year. 

•Luck plays a small part in how your experience will turn out in NCS due to the allocation of projects. 

•Few fresh grads are interested in infrastructure roles, more are interested in software, data etc. Thus, almost half of the staff is non-Singaporeans. 

•Remuneration needs to be reviewed frequently. The gap between new joiners and those who have stayed in the company long is widening

• Management needs to learn to ask “why” when someone resigns, and not just let the person leave.

- Opportunity to sell Cloud, Infra, Application, Security
- Great place to join if you can't find a job anywhere else in the market because the above 2 reasons will vastly widen the depth and breath of your experience, so you'll be more sought after when you decide to leave NCS.
cons:
- Very High Turnover rate for Account Managers in certain teams
- Within the last 1+ year some accounts have had up to 2 or 3 diff AMs
- Key questions to ask when interviewing for the AM role at NCS are:

Is this a new or replacement role?
Why did the previous AM leave?
How many AMs has this set of accounts had in the last 1 to 2 years?
What is the average tenure of the AM in your team?
How are the AMs being set up for success?
Is the sales quota fixed or does it change arbitrarily over time?
What policies are in place to ensure that the mental and emotional well being of the AMs are being taken care of?

Go in with your eyes wide open so that your expectations are level with reality.

review_title: Exciting new journey for a transformed
pros: The transformation and changes creates an environment where new ways of working and new ideas are very much welcomed. Customer are better served and new value is being created for both employees (thru interesting work) and customers (thru a NCS with more skills and a wider service offerings).
cons: All transitions are challenging. It is like changing the engine of an airplane while still flying. Being involved and part of the change is not easy. It will require each person to personally buy into the change and make the change themselves.

pros: They have the best benefits in form of paid leaves. Apart from annual and sick / hospitalization leaves, they gave employees an extra 5 days of paid flexi leave which we can use for birthday, child care or family care. They strongly encourage employees to constantly self-upgrade and thus provided us with 7 days of paid skills advancement leave.
cons: As a subsidiary, every aspect of company's management is controlled by Singtel. Thus, it has a 'very' tall organization. Too tall that it can take up to 2 weeks or more to get through a high ranking manager. Have to go through all the ladder of hierachy, or otherwise no one will entertain you. Also, middle management of certain departments tend to take credit of the hardwork of the lower ranking employees. Thus, if you start at the lowest rank, the chances of career advancement are about 10 years or never. However if NCS is on its own, all the lower ranking employees might get their deserving career advancement. Afterall, unlike Singtel, NCS have been making profits for the entire organization over the years (even during covid-19 pandemic period).

pros: I joined NCS at the point when it was embarking on a major transformation. This transformation ushers in new technological capabilities putting NCS at the forefront of digital technology, AI, 5G, cloud, robotics, etc to revolutionize commercial businesses and public sectors in their digital adoption journey. NCS sees itself playing a crucial role in building our communities and improving the lives of Singaporeans. It has been an exciting and purposeful new chapter for me since joining the NCS family. Contrary to some, I find that NCS genuinely cares about the well-being of its staff. The senior leaders walk the talk to ensure that staff are cared for, valued and developed to the best of their abilities. Making extraordinary happen is not just a tagline - NCS is living it and is indeed an exciting and dynamic place to join. Regardless of whether you are a fresh graduate or mid-careerist, join NCS if you are looking for a rewarding place that can challenge you and bring purpose to what you do.
cons: Some may find NCS a demanding place, lacking work-life balance. It is indeed true that NCS is demanding, but it is a place for someone who is passionate about technology, who has resilience and drive and who finds purpose in contributing to our communities, to shine. NCS is fair to its staff and cares about them - maintaining staff work-life balance is essential to NCS and I personally witness the continuous process of senior management partnering and conversing with the staff to strike a meaningful balance.

review_title: Discourage performer on HR Policy on Appraisal
job_title: SAP Senior Consultant in Ang Mo Kio New Town,
pros:
Appraisal rating cannot jump or drop 2 rating, so it is good for those start of with high rating, than can 'lukewarm' the work.

As long as customer like you... you are safe for the job (usually government project.. so politic too priority)
cons:
Prevent staffs to perform as it doesn't allow 2 jump rating in appraisal per year.

Don't join during the appraisal month and align with confirmation as it was not a fair HR policy if got bad rating for first appraisal.

Unfair to staff that was appraised only 3 months then that rating with HR bad policy about not jumping 2 rate in a year surely discourage the staff to look forward... so my advice.. once get lower appraisal rate for a start... left the job because the appraisal is not constructive... it have a system of demotivate once the start rating is low (often when start, there are learning curve then penalty on the first appraisal plus bad progression of the HR appraisal policy... it have destroyed the staff career)

Remember : no point stay once the first appraisal rating is not so good as it have a HR policy for staff to made right in quick 1 year. (Very sad on such HR policy)

review_title: Dull third rate IT company filled with "retirees"  & "server guys"
job_title: Director in Ang Mo Kio New Town,
pros:
Good salary (for those who are poached), Decent benefits

If you are the type who likes to work in a SME then NCS is a good place for u. It is a very "local" company where singlish is the default modus operandi. Almost all their projects are from govt and because NCS is govt linked, you dont even need to work so hard to innovate and improve. Every single contract is more than 5 years. 

Additionally, if you have kids then you are in luck. Their AMK office has a in house nursery place where your kids can go.

If you are the kind of who just happy for minimal work and no progression, just a stable income, NCS is right for you.
cons:
The entire organisation is filled with old , middle aged employees who worked in one organization in their entire life, thus the lack of competitiveness and inertness. 

As a govt linked company, almost all their projects are in a way "awarded by default" to the, thence the lack of drive to innovate. Everyone at the middle level are just "keeping the lights on".

The admin staff in NCS are just ridiculously laid back. 1 entire week to get your account and laptop ready when you joined. By 1130am, you can see the admin staff queuing to get into the free shuttle bus to go to the nearby suburb mall for lunch. By 5 plus, all of them are queuing to get to the same bus to go home.

Forget about all the fancy updates you see in NCS, its a boring inert old school IT company that brings zero value to your CV
